channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Bitcoin now legal tender in El Salvador, first nation to adopt cryptocurrency
item.description: Central American nation hopes to lower remittance costs and boost investment.

item.title: Google kills its augmented reality “Measure” app
item.description: App let you measure things with your smartphone.

item.title: Battlefield 2042 will host 128-player combat on PC, next-gen consoles Oct. 22
item.description: Last-gen versions top out at 64 players; no single-player campaign this time.

item.title: Lordstown Motors warns its electric vehicle business may fail
item.description: Stock falls after filing flags “substantial doubt” over future operations.

item.title: RTX 3070 Ti review: Nvidia leaves the GPU fast lane (for now)
item.description: Nvidia thought you wanted faster VRAM for this “Ti,” not more. Was Nvidia right?

item.title: Hackers can mess with HTTPS connections by sending data to your email server
item.description: Cross-protocol attacks could potentially steal login cookies or execute malicious code.

item.title: A “disgraceful decision:” Researchers blast FDA for approving Alzheimer’s drug
item.description: Even the FDA’s own advisers and statisticians didn’t think the drug should be approved.

item.title: Spurred by Clarence Thomas, Ohio AG wants Google declared a public utility
item.description: Ohio lawsuit quotes Justice Thomas' opinion that websites can be common carriers.

item.title: Fast.ly broke the Internet for an hour this morning
item.description: Every redundant system still has single points of failure—usually human.

item.title: Pick up a recommended pair of Anker noise-canceling headphones for $60
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Logitech mice, Razer accessories, and more.

item.title: Buried features: There’s more to macOS Monterey than the keynote let on
item.description: Overhauled password management, compatibility, low power, and more.

item.title: Apple TV’s summer preview includes tantalizing glimpses of Foundation series
item.description: It’s not much, but we’ll take it.

item.title: Branson may make a last-ditch effort to beat Bezos into space
item.description: “At this time, we have not determined the date of our next flight.”

item.title: FBI sold phones to organized crime and read 27 million “encrypted” messages
item.description: Messages were routed to an FBI-owned server and decrypted with master key.

item.title: Google’s revamped Wear OS sounds like a clean break from the old version
item.description: Existing Qualcomm hardware is so obsolete it would probably hold the platform back.

item.title: Amazon and Walmart try—again—to upend prescription drug prices
item.description: Prescription drug market has proven hard to change.

item.title: Playdate, the console with a crank, gets July preorder for $179, game details
item.description: Today’s news: 24 “season one” games, optional stereo, free browser-based dev kit.

item.title: The WF-1000XM4 is Sony’s noise-canceling answer to the AirPods Pro
item.description: Hands-on: $280 earbuds feature new design and promise improved noise canceling.

item.title: Solar farms could double as pollinator food supplies
item.description: To fight pollinator decline, 8 states put habitats alongside solar facilities.

item.title: Review: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart doesn’t reinvent the franchise—and that’s OK
item.description: A solid entry in a solid series, at least when it gets out of its own way.

item.title: Relativity has a bold plan to take on SpaceX, and investors are buying it
item.description: “We’re trying to ice skate to where the puck is going.”

item.title: Ford builds an affordable, efficient small truck: The new Maverick
item.description: This small hybrid truck gets 40 mpg in the city and starts at $19,995.

item.title: Nvidia and Valve are bringing DLSS to Linux gaming… sort of
item.description: Nice, but we’d prefer significantly greater investment in native driver quality.

item.title: These forged 17th-century music books went undetected for a century
item.description: Penn State musicologist Marica Tacconi discovered the fakes on sabbatical in Venice.

item.title: US may miss July 4 vaccination target as number of daily doses plummets
item.description: Biden aimed to have 70% of adults immunized by July 4. The country may fall short.

item.title: US seizes $2.3 million Colonial Pipeline paid to ransomware attackers
item.description: Funds seized after Justice Department IDs Bitcoin wallet and obtains its private key.

item.title: 18 months after launch, Google Stadia now supports Android TV
item.description: Google’s video game service finally works on Google’s TV platform.

item.title: $1 billion piracy ruling could force ISPs to disconnect more Internet users
item.description: Increased account terminations would punish “innocent” users, groups tell court.

item.title: watchOS 8 brings new health and messaging features to the Apple Watch this year
item.description: Apple walks through what to expect from the Watch’s next major software update.

item.title: Apple announces macOS Monterey, the next Mac desktop operating system
item.description: Latest macOS release follows on the heels of Big Sur redesign last year.

item.title: Apple announces iOS 15 and iPadOS 15
item.description: The iPad will get the same home screen features the iPhone received last year.

item.title: Schumacher, Senna, and co-op multiplayer are new additions for F1 2021
item.description: We interviewed franchise director Lee Mather about this year’s installment.

item.title: Liveblog: All the news from Apple’s WWDC 2021 keynote today at 1 pm ET
item.description: Get your updates about iOS, macOS, and more here on June 7 at 10 am Pacific.

item.title: Antitrust settlement forces Google to revamp ad platform
item.description: “Google took advantage of its vertical integration,” French regulator says.

item.title: Jeff Bezos says he will fly into space next month
item.description: “You can buy Soyuz seats; it’s not what drives me.”

item.title: Woman in Motion tells story of how Star Trek’s Uhura changed NASA forever
item.description: “If they let me in the door, I will open it so wide that they will see the world.”

item.title: Ancient electric cars meet modern EVs at Amelia Island show
item.description: Where else can you see a 1.5 hp 1895 Electrobat next to a 1,000 hp Hummer EV?

item.title: Here’s why TSMC and Intel keep building foundries in the Arizona desert
item.description: Fresh water supply isn’t the only consideration for chip fabrication.

item.title: 24-inch iMac review: There’s still no step three
item.description: It’s not Apple’s best for power users, but it’s a nice fit for everyone else.

item.title: When the bison come back, will the ecosystem follow?
item.description: Bring wild bison to the Great Plains, restore one of the world’s most endangered ecosystems.

item.title: Hacker lexicon: What is a supply chain attack?
item.description: From NotPetya to SolarWinds, it’s a problem that’s not going away any time soon.

item.title: The best early Prime Day deal gives $10 Amazon credit with a $40 gift card
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Audible, Resident Evil, and PlayStation Plus.

item.title: Reducing poverty can actually lower energy demand, finds research
item.description: Turns out human development is a matter of economic justice and climate justice.

item.title: “Kind of crazy”—how the booming US used car market is driving inflation
item.description: Supply constraints and soaring demand have made vehicle prices a key number for the Fed.

item.title: There’s hope for American movie theaters after all
item.description: COVID-19 crushed movie chains—A Quiet Place Part II’s box office shows a potential way out.

item.title: Early adopters of Chinese vaccines see case surges; China plows ahead anyway
item.description: China is now giving 20 million doses a day despite low efficacy.

item.title: Puppies’ ability to communicate with people is present almost from birth
item.description: We might one day be able to predict which puppies will make the best service dogs.

item.title: This is not a drill: VMware vuln with 9.8 severity rating is under attack
item.description: Code execution flaw in vCenter is exploited to install web shell on unpatched machines.

item.title: Yes, the military is serious about rocketing supplies around the planet
item.description: “A rocket can get around the world in 90 minutes, and an airplane cannot.”

item.title: “Deleted” Nintendo floppy recovered 26 years later, full of Earthbound secrets
item.description: Oil massages, mantras, zombie kidnappings, and more—with ROM-hacked footage to prove it.

item.title: Researchers perform magic tricks for birds, who are not amused
item.description: Can an animal without hands recognize when humans are using sleight-of-hand tricks?

item.title: Google makes small Android advertising concession in wake of iOS 14.5
item.description: Android ad tracking still isn’t opt-in, though, so not much will change.
